title-group.article-title: Effect of School-Initiated Parent Outreach Activities on Parent Involvement in School Events

author-notes.corresp: Leigh Ann Frew, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843-4225, USA. Email: leighanneisterhold@gmail.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: SEELS and NLTS2 National Databases

abstract.p: Parent involvement is a cornerstone of special education policy and best practice. Parents of students with disabilities participate in school events in a manner similar to parents of students without disabilities, and the benefits of parent involvement are widely recognized for all students. Recent legislation and federal funding opportunities have targeted parent outreach programs as an area of improvement for schools. Using data from the Special Education Elementary Longitudinal Study, this study examined the effect of school-initiated parent outreach activities on parent involvement in school. Parents reported greater involvement in schools that offered a greater number of outreach activities. Parent involvement was lower for older students, non-Caucasian students, students from non-two-parent households, and students from lower income households, and these lower participation rates were not differentially higher in schools that offered a greater number of parent outreach activities. Patterns and trends of parent involvement and school-initiated outreach programs are discussed, with suggestions for practitioners and future research.

body.p: Research in general education has documented a strong link between a child’s success in school and parent involvement in school-sponsored activities such as participating in a general schoolwide meeting (e.g., a Parent Teacher Association/Parent Teacher Organization meeting), attending a school/class event (e.g., a musical performance), and volunteering at school (e.g., serving on a committee). The importance of these benefits is emphasized at all ages, including the adolescent years (Catsambis, 2001). Benefits of strong parent involvement include more favorable social/emotional outcomes for students, as more involved parents are associated with less disruptive student behavior in school (Gutman & Midgley, 2000; Sanders & Herting, 2000), higher school engagement (Simons-Morton & Chen, 2009), greater student motivation, and academic achievement (Andrews & Duncan, 1997; Aunola, Stattin, & Nurmi, 2000; Barber & Olsen, 2003). Many school-related benefits exist: Higher levels of parent involvement is a significant indicator of higher grades (Sirin & Rogers-Sirin, 2004), better attendance (Haynes, Comer, & Hamilton-Lee, 1989), higher graduation rates (Fan & Chen, 2001; Gutman & Midgley, 2000; Sanders & Herting, 2000), and higher overall academic achievement (Hill & Craft, 2003; Ho Sui-Chu & Willms, 1996).

Research in general education has also documented that parent involvement in school-sponsored activities is associated with certain student and family demographic factors. Specifically, parents are more involved during elementary school compared with their children’s middle school years (Hoover-Dempsey & Sandler, 1997; Mo & Singh, 2008), the level of school involvement decreasing as students age (Downs, 2001; Johnston, 1998). Furthermore, differences in level of parent involvement are associated with ethnicity. The U.S. Department of Education (2003) found African American and Hispanic parents less likely than Caucasian parents to attend general school meetings and events. Fan and Chen (2001) noted that ethnicity had a negligible effect on the relationship between parental involvement and academic achievement in a meta-analysis of the effects of parent involvement across grade levels. Typically, higher socioeconomic status (SES) is correlated with higher levels of parent involvement (Berends, 1995; Brody & Flor, 1998; Fan & Chen, 2001). An early National Education Longitudinal Study found parents to be more involved with schools on behalf of their sons than their daughters (Carter & Wojtkiewicz, 2000), but other studies have not found significant differences in parent participation rates in terms of student gender.

As important as parent involvement is to the education of students without disabilities, it can be argued that it is even more important for students with disabilities. Parent involvement is embedded in federal law and policy, and it is a cornerstone of best practice. The term parent involvement appears 1,299 times in the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act of 2004, with Indicator 8 requiring states to report the percentage of parents who felt that schools facilitated parent involvement (Michigan Department of Education, 2010). For the 2007–2008 school year, 24 states did not meet their target percentage for this measure (Elbaum, 2009). Many parents felt schools did not adequately initiate outreach activities to increase parent involvement.

Given the importance assigned to parent involvement by special education policy and practice, there is a surprisingly small body of research on parent involvement in special education, especially compared with research on parent involvement in general education.

The existing research indicates that approximately 90% of parents of students with disabilities are involved in the Individualized Education Program process across the elementary, middle, and high school years (Blackorby et al., 2007; Newman, 2005), a form of parent involvement that is unique to special education. Parents of students with disabilities participate at levels comparable with those of parents of students without disabilities in schoolwide meetings (77% vs. 70%), class events (62% vs. 59%), and volunteer opportunities (24% vs. 26%) (Newman, 2005).

Family involvement benefits students with disabilities. Parent involvement in school-sponsored activities at the preschool level has been shown to be related to better early reading skills (Calderon, 2000) and later academic achievement (Miedel & Reynolds, 1999) for students with disabilities. However, the benefits of greater involvement by parents of students with disabilities during elementary and middle school grades have been mixed. For example, Blackorby et al. (2007) found that greater levels of parent involvement in school activities was associated with higher reading performance and grades, greater participation by students in school groups, and fewer disciplinary actions. However, most of these findings did not retain significance when all variables were considered in their models. Zhang, Hsu, Kwok, Benz, and Bowman-Perrott (2011) found no significant relationships between greater levels of parent involvement in school activities and student academic achievement. For middle and high school students with disabilities, greater levels of parent involvement in school-sponsored activities have been shown to be related to better performance in reading, better grades, and greater levels of student involvement in school activities and groups (Newman, 2005).

Although the research is limited, evidence suggests that rates of involvement in school-sponsored activities by parents of students with disabilities vary based on student and family characteristics that parallel research findings for parents of students without disabilities. Findings from a nationwide study of middle and high school students with disabilities indicate that parents with higher (vs. lower) household incomes, parents with higher (vs. lower) levels of education, and parents from two-parent (vs. single-parent) families were more involved in school-sponsored activities (Newman, 2005; Zhang et al., 2011). In the same study, parents of older students (vs. younger students) and parents of African American students (vs. Caucasian students) were less involved in school activities. In a departure from the findings on parents of students without disabilities, parents of females with disabilities were more involved in school activities than parents of male students.

If parent involvement in school is associated with better student outcomes, a key question is whether schools can engage in outreach activities that encourage and promote greater levels of parent participation. National organizations such as the National Parent-Teacher Association (PTA Family-School Partnerships, 2009), the National Middle School Association (Pate & Andrews, 2006), and the Partnerships for Families Initiative (Center for the Study of Social Policy, 2010) have provided guidelines, recommendations, and materials to help schools promote greater levels of parent/family involvement in school activities. Recommendations include (a) providing parents with information regarding their child’s development at each stage (Mo & Singh, 2008); (b) offering parenting workshops, trainings, and family support programs (Flynn & Nolan, 2008); (c) developing newsletters and other materials in parents’ native languages and making materials concise and easy to understand (Elish-Piper, 2008); (d) informing parents of school activities, projects, and cocurricular activities (Mo & Singh, 2008); and (e) encouraging parents to become part of decision-making committees (Flynn & Nolan, 2008). Although little specific information exists on the efficacy of these outreach efforts to increase parent involvement, Green, Walker, Hoover-Dempsey, and Sandler (2007) found that parent involvement in school activities was associated with parent perceptions that the school encouraged greater parent involvement.

In summary, parent involvement is a cornerstone of special education policy and best practice. Like parents of students without disabilities, parents of students with disabilities participate in school-sponsored activities such as schoolwide meetings, class events, and volunteer opportunities. Participation rates vary for individual activities, ranging from approximately 25% (volunteering in school) to approximately 70% (attending a schoolwide meeting). Furthermore, rates of participation vary based on certain student (e.g., age, ethnicity) and family (income, number of parents in household) characteristics.

Although the research base is more limited in special education than in general education, evidence suggests that greater levels of parent involvement in school activities are associated with academic and social benefits for students with disabilities. Finally, there is some evidence in general education that school-initiated outreach activities are associated with greater levels of parent involvement, but to date, no research has examined the relationship between school-initiated parent outreach activities and levels of parent involvement in school for students with disabilities.

Given the importance of parent involvement in special education, such research is needed. For these reasons, this study examined the relationship between school-initiated parent outreach activities and levels of parent involvement in school. The Special Education Elementary Longitudinal Study (SEELS) data set was used to conduct this research. Variables were extracted from the data set to examine selected student- and school-level predictors on parent involvement in school. In addition, the unique contributions of school-initiated parent outreach activities, a 16-item variable in the data set, to parent involvement in school were examined. The primary research question investigated in this study was as follows: “Do school-initiated parent outreach activities predict greater levels of parent involvement in school, holding other student- and school-level predictors constant?”

sec.title: Participants and Procedures
sec.p: Participants and data for this study were drawn from the SEELS, a nationwide study to investigate the needs, experiences, and outcomes of students with disabilities. SEELS was funded by the U.S. Department of Education and conducted by SRI International. Detailed information on the SEELS design is provided elsewhere (Wagner, Kutash, Duchnowski, & Epstein, 2005; Wagner, Marder, Blackorby, & Cardoso, 2002) and summarized here. Data were collected in three waves over a 6-year period between the 1999–2000 and 2004–2005 school years on a nationally representative sample of students who were between the ages of 6 and 12 at the start of the study. Data were gathered through parent interviews, teacher and school administrator questionnaires, and direct student assessments.

SEELS participants were selected through a two-stage sampling process to produce a nationally representative sample. First, a stratified sample of 1,124 districts was selected based on district size, geographic location, and wealth. A total of 245 local school districts and 32 special schools agreed to participate in the study, and from these schools, a stratified (primary disability) random sample of 11,512 students was selected to participate in the Wave 1 parent interview/survey data collection process. Participants for the current study consisted of 9,747 students with Wave 1 parent interview/survey data.

Once all missing data were accounted for across all variables, the final sample for the study included 3,138 participants. Demographic information on the original SEELS sample and this study’s sample is included in Table 1 (descriptive statistics are based on unweighted data). Chi-square tests (for categorical variables) and t tests (for continuous variables) were conducted to compare group differences in the demographic characteristics of students with complete information and students with missing data. No group differences were found on gender, primary disability, or family SES. However, student age was significantly different between the two groups (t = −5.33, p = .00, d = −.12): The two groups differed by .21 years (roughly 2 months) in age. Compared with the original SEELS sample, the final sample for the present study included greater percentages of students from Caucasian families (63% vs. 69%) and students from two-parent families (66% vs. 72%).

fn.p: Note: SEELS = Special Education Elementary Longitudinal Study; SES = socioeconomic status. Descriptive statistics are based on unweighted data.

sec.title: Dependent variable: Parent participation in school events
sec.p: Consistent with previous research on parent involvement in school (e.g., Newman, 2005), three parent-reported items were selected to measure parent participation in school events. Specifically, parents reported (no = 0, yes = 1) whether in the prior school year the parent or another adult in the household (a) participated in a general school meeting, (b) attended a school/class event, or (c) volunteered at school. We examined a single factor model (comparative fit index = 0.95, root mean square error of approximation = 0.02, and weighted root mean square residual = 1.01) with the three dichotomous variables loaded on it using the type = complex routine with robust estimation method (weighted least squares mean and variance adjusted) in Mplus (V.6.1; Muthén & Muthén, 1998–2010). The standardized factor loadings of these three items ranged from .58 to .77, indicating that they did relate substantially to each other (or share a significant amount of common variance). Thus, scores on the individual items were summed to create a composite parent participation variable, which was basically normally distributed (M = 2.04, SD = 0.94, skewness = −.64, and kurtosis = −.59). Scores ranged from 0 to 3, with a score of 3 indicating that the parent reported participating in all three events in the prior school year.

sec.title: Student-level predictor variables
sec.p: Based on the literature reviewed earlier, six student-level variables (four student demographic variables and two family characteristics variables) were extracted from the SEELS database as possible predictors of parent participation in school activities. The following four student demographic variables were selected: primary disability, ethnicity, gender, and student age. Primary disability was a dummy-coded variable used to control for any variance associated with disability. It was coded as a dichotomous variable (emotional disturbance = 1, other disabilities = 0) based on previous research, indicating that patterns of family involvement for students with emotional disturbance (ED) often vary from those of other students with disabilities (Duchnowski & Kutash, 2011; Newman, 2005). Ethnicity was also coded as a dichotomous variable (non-Caucasian = 0, Caucasian = 1) to reflect the differential parent participation patterns evidenced in previous research. In addition, there were no significant mean differences on the dependent variable (parent participation in school events) for students in different racial or ethnic groups, F = 1.68; p = .15. Gender was also coded dichotomously (female = 0, male = 1). Student age was treated as a continuous variable.

Two family characteristics variables were selected: family household structure and family SES. Parents reported whether their child lived in a two-parent household at the time data were collected (coded as 1). Other family structures (e.g., single, divorced parent; single, widowed parent) were coded as non-two-parent families (value = 0). Family SES was a composite variable that included (a) whether family income was below the poverty level (a variable in the SEELS data set that was coded “yes = 0” and “no = 1”), (b) whether a member of the family used benefits from any of three federal benefit programs (Supplemental Security Income, food stamps, and/or Temporary Assistance for Needy Families; coded “yes to any = 0” and “no = 1”), and (c) whether the education level of the head of household was less than a high school diploma (coded “yes = 0” and “no = 1”). A composite sum score of the three dichotomous variables ranged from 0 (low SES) to 3 (high SES).

sec.title: School-level predictor variables
sec.p: Six school-level predictor variables were extracted from the SEELS database: urban school, school enrollment, school (student) mobility rate, percentage of student population on free/reduced-price lunch, number of school-initiated parent outreach activities, and principal evaluation of outreach activities. Urban school referred to whether the student’s school was in an urban location (coded “no = 0” and “yes = 1”). School enrollment was the total number of students enrolled in the school at the time of data collection as reported by the principal. School mobility rate, as reported by the school principal, indicated the percentage of students enrolled in the school in the prior year who moved away from school during the school year. The free/reduced-price lunch variable as reported by the school principal indicated the percentage of the student population eligible for the free or reduced-price lunch program (coded “≤25% = 1,” “26%–50% = 2,” “51%–75% = 3,” and “≥75% = 4”).

School-initiated parent outreach activities were reported by the school principal. Principals indicated whether the school offered (a) open house or back-to-school night; (b) regularly scheduled schoolwide parent–teacher conferences; (c) school events to which parents were invited; (d) workshops or courses on parenting; (e) written contact between school and parent; (f) parent–student learning activities at school; (g) parents as volunteers in the school; (h) a newsletter for parents; (i) opportunities for parents to be involved in instructional issues; (j) opportunities for parents to be involved in school governance activities; (k) a schoolwide email list, web page, or homework hotline; (l) services to support parent involvement; (m) translation of school materials into languages other than English; (n) educational programs for parents; (o) a parent liaison program; or (p) a family resource center or drop-in center. A sum score that ranged from 1 to 16 was calculated to indicate the total number of school-initiated parent outreach activities.

The final school-level variable, evaluation of parent outreach activities, described the principal’s level of agreement with the following statement: “This school does a good job of reaching out to parents who are typically not involved at the school.” Principals rated their level of agreement with this statement on a 4-point scale that ranged from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). It was a measure of perceived success of school outreach efforts to parents. Descriptive information on the school-level predictors is presented in Table 2 (values based on unweighted data).

fn.p: Note: Descriptive statistics are based on unweighted data.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: As noted earlier, SEELS participants were selected through a two-stage sampling process. The first stage involved selecting local education agencies based on three sampling stratifiers. Within the SEELS data set, school-level data provided by principals were linked to students attending the school, but the specific school that students attended was not identified (SRI International, 2005). Given the nested nature of the data and the desire to investigate student and school-level variables as predictors of parent involvement, the researchers in this study approximated a school ID by using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (2010; V.18) “data aggregation” routine. An aggregated file matched student data on the six school-level variables used in the analysis (i.e., urban school, school enrollment, percentage of students receiving free or reduced lunch, student mobility rate, principal evaluation of outreach activities, and school-initiated outreach activities); students who had exactly the same values on these six school-level variables were grouped together and assigned the same school ID. Based on the aggregated data, 1,367 schools were estimated, and we obtained the intraclass correlation coefficient (0.12) and the corresponding design effect statistic (1.23). Design effect (Hox & Maas, 2002; Kish, 1965) can be viewed as the indicator of the magnitude of underestimation in the standard errors when multilevel data are analyzed with a single-level model (e.g., ordinary least squares regression). According to Muthén and Satorra’s (1995) recommendation (as cited by Hox & Maas, 2002), “If the design effect is smaller than two, using single-level analysis on multilevel data does not seem to lead to overly misleading results” (p. 5). Given that the design effect based on the created school ID was smaller than 2, analyzing the SEELS data with a single-level model would result in acceptable parameter estimates and standard errors. Nevertheless, we still analyzed the data with a two-level model in which the created school IDs were the Level 2 units and the students were the Level 1 units given that the intraclass correlation was not equal to zero, indicating the existence of dependency among the observations (students) in the data. The conditional model was then fitted in HLM (V.7) as below:

sec.title: Results
sec.p: As shown in Table 3, several student-level variables were associated with parent involvement in school events. Parents of younger students participated more than parents of older students in general school meetings, school/class events, or volunteering at school (γ10 = −0.04, p < .001). Parents of Caucasian students participated in school events more than parents of non-Caucasian students (γ30 = 0.16, p < 0.001). In addition, higher SES families demonstrated higher levels of parent involvement than lower SES families (γ50 = 0.24, p < .001), and parents of children in two-parent households (compared with non-two-parent households) were more likely to be involved in school events (γ60 = 0.14, p < .001). Student gender (γ20 = 0.03, ns) and primary disability (γ40 = −0.26, ns) were unrelated to parent involvement in school events.

caption.p: Fixed Effects Estimates and Variance–Covariance Estimates for Model of Parent Participation in School Events.

fn.p: Note: ED = emotional disturbance; SES = socioeconomic status.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are small and close to 0.

sec.p: With regard to school-level predictors, parent involvement in school events was lower in schools in which a higher percentage of the student population was eligible for free or reduced-price lunch (γ03 = −0.07, p < .001). Furthermore, parent involvement in school events was higher in schools that offered a greater number of parent outreach activities (γ06 = 0.02, p < .01). No other school-level variables of interest were associated with parent involvement in school events.

As noted earlier, we were particularly interested in the relationship between school-initiated parent outreach activities and parent involvement in school events. Given the finding that parent involvement was higher in schools that offered a greater number of parent outreach activities, all two-way cross-level interaction effects between the school-initiated parent outreach activities and all the student-level variables associated with parent involvement were tested in the hierarchical linear model, including Age × School Outreach Activities (γ = 0.002; p = .63), Ethnicity_Caucasian × School Outreach Activities (γ = −0.005; p = .69), Disability_ED × School Outreach Activities (γ = 0.01; p = .58), Family SES × School Outreach Activities (γ = −0.006; p = .54), and Two-Parent Household × School Outreach Activities(γ = 0.003; p = .82). None of these interaction terms were significant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Generally, parents of students with disabilities participate in school events at levels comparable with those of parents of students without disabilities. For both groups of parents, participation rates vary based on certain student and family characteristics. Schools nationwide are being encouraged to increase parent and family involvement in school activities, and several national organizations have provided guidelines and recommendations for improving school and family partnerships. Yet, little research documented whether school-initiated parent outreach activities increases parent involvement in school events. The present study was designed to fill this void by investigating the effect of school-initiated parent outreach activities on parent involvement in school events for a sample of students with disabilities drawn from the SEELS.

Similar to earlier research (e.g., Downs, 2001; Fan & Chen, 2001; Johnston, 1998; Newman, 2005), parent participation in school events (e.g., attending a general school meeting, attending a school/class event, and volunteering at school) was found to be related to several key student and family characteristics. Specifically, higher family SES, being a two-parent household, and being Caucasian were characteristics associated with higher levels of parent participation in school events. Lower levels of parent participation in school events were associated with parents of older students.

This study adds to the research on parent involvement for students with disabilities by showing that school-initiated parent outreach activities are associated with higher reported parent participation in school events. For students in this study, parents reported greater involvement in school events in schools that reported offering a greater number of parent outreach activities.

When we examined possible interaction effects between school-initiated parent outreach activities and the student and family characteristics associated with parent involvement, we found no statistically significant interaction effects. These findings of nonsignificance should be interpreted cautiously, however. Although rates of parent participation in school events was higher overall in schools that offered a greater number of parent outreach activities, the differences in rates of participation by certain parent groups did not decrease (e.g., the participation gap between low-income vs. high-income parents did not decrease). Research in general education (Green et al., 2007) indicates that actual parent involvement in school events is associated with parent perceptions that the school encourages parent involvement. Whether relationships exist among the number of school-initiated parent outreach activities, positive parent perceptions of school efforts, and higher levels of parent participation in school events remains unclear at this point and should be a focus of future research. Parent assessment of the relevance and quality of school outreach activities, and the relationship of student and family demographic characteristics to parent assessments of relevance and quality, should also be investigated in future research.

Current parent involvement definitions and policies have been criticized as disregarding the needs of low-SES families by focusing on activities more commonly engaged in by middle- and upper SES families (de Carvalho, 2001; Mapp, 2003; Smith, 2006). School professionals attempting to forge family–school partnerships sometimes lack the evidence-based knowledge and skills to effectively establish these relationships (Jordan, Orozco, & Averett, 2001). Schools seeking to increase parent involvement might consider adding outreach programs that appeal to a wide cross-section of families. For example, the suggestions from parent–teacher organizations, including parent liaisons, welcome centers, and resource centers (PTA Family-School Partnerships, 2009) could help bolster the parent–school relationship as each party recognizes the benefits of increased parent involvement. Furthermore, many resources and strategies aimed at increasing parent involvement for general education could support special education family involvement as well. In a review of commercial parent involvement programs, Mbwana, Terzian, and Moore (2009) identified technology components (such as telephone-based interactions and computer software) as effective. Encouraging active parent–teacher organization involvement for low-income and underrepresented ethnic groups can also be an effective way for schools to target underinvolved groups (Desimone, 1999). Finally, Smith (2006) suggested that partnerships with local agencies, businesses, and churches can increase parent involvement of low-income families. In short, an alternative to offering more programs could be focusing resources on improving the programs and outreach efforts that schools have found to be most effective.

Gonzalez-DeHass and Willems (2003) recommended that preservice teacher education programs make students aware of the obstacles parents and schools could face with regard to improving family–school relationships. For example, this might be achieved through field experiences working with families or dialogue with professionals who are initiating and maintaining successful home–school partnerships.

sec.title: Limitations and Recommendations for Future Research
sec.p: The study was subject to three limitations. First, the variables included in this study were based on self-report data from parents and school principals. If parents felt it was socially desirable to report they were involved in their student’s school in the previous school year, it is possible that they overrated the extent of their involvement. Similarly, if some principals felt it was desirable to report that their school provided parent outreach activities, they might have overreported the efforts taken by their school to promote parent involvement. Second, sampling weights were not used. As a result, the findings should not be generalized to the national population of students with disabilities and their families. Third, the study used the extant data set from the SEELS study to investigate the effect of school-initiated parent outreach activities on parent involvement. Large data sets such as the SEELS study permit multivariate investigations of important issues. However, the breadth of such databases can limit the depth of information on any specific variables of interest. With regard to the present study, for example, the SEELS data set did not include information on parents’ assessments of the quality of schools’ outreach activities or parent identification of school-initiated activities that would best meet their family’s needs and thus encourage greater family involvement in school. Such information could permit a more in-depth understanding of how to encourage greater parent involvement and should be considered in future research.

More research is needed on the effectiveness of different outreach programs on parent involvement. Are some outreach activities more successful than others in encouraging participation from families of different sociodemographic characteristics? How do families from different sociodemographic groups define parent involvement? What do these families identify as strategies schools can implement to support greater parent and family involvement? Research from our study is consistent with earlier research indicating that parent involvement in school diminishes as students age. How do families from different sociodemographic define parent involvement during the secondary and transition years when more family involvement may help develop transition plans and plan for postsecondary outcomes?

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although the benefits of parent involvement in schools have been highlighted in previous studies (e.g., Gutman & Midgley, 2000; Sanders & Herting, 2000; Sirin & Rogers-Sirin, 2004), given the importance assigned to parent involvement in special education policy and best practice, surprisingly little research has examined patterns of parent involvement for students with disabilities and factors associated with higher levels of involvement. The results of the present study provide preliminary evidence that school-initiated parent outreach programs are associated with higher levels of parent involvement in school events. More research is needed to establish an evidence base for practices that will increase the involvement of all parents of students with disabilities, regardless of sociodemographic background.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
